Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Situation2: They coordinate closely with contractors to keep the construction schedule on track.
Story:
My phone buzzed violently on the nightstand, jolting me awake. It was Sam, my oldest friend, his voice shaky and desperate. His car had broken down on the highway, miles from anywhere, and he needed me—now. I promised I’d figure something out, but as I hung up, my heart pounded for another reason. Tomorrow at dawn, I was supposed to meet the contractors at the new site. The concrete pour was scheduled for 6 a.m., and any delay would throw the whole project off, costing the firm thousands and risking my reputation as a reliable architect.

I sat on the edge of my bed, torn. Sam had always been there for me, and I knew he was counting on me to show up. But my team and the contractors were expecting me to lead, to keep everything running smoothly. I could already imagine the disappointed faces, the angry calls from my boss, the ripple effect of a missed deadline. My mind raced, weighing loyalty against responsibility, friendship against professionalism, as the minutes ticked by and I still hadn’t moved.
